Graphical abstract This review summarized and critically discussed the current strategies to achieve longevity of lithium-selenium batteries by promoting the retention of active Se inventory and highly efficient utilization of Se-containing species. Lithium-selenium (Li-Se) batteries have attracted increasing attention as one of the next-generation battery systems due to much higher electronic conductivity and comparable volumetric capacity of Se compared to the popular sulfur cathode. However, its practical application still faces great challenges, especially the rapid capacity decay triggered by the loss of active Se species. A comprehensive review to uncover the in-depth failure mechanism and provide targeted solutions to promote the stable operation of Li-Se batteries is urgently needed. This review systematically summarizes the strategies in the new perspective, focusing on the optimization of Se utilization in Li-Se batteries by keeping a high Se maintenance in the cathode and accelerating the electrochemical kinetics of lithium polyselenides (LiPSe) conversion. On the basis of structural design and Li2Se active material introduction to accommodate volume expansion, blocking shuttle transport of LiPSe by physical/chemical adsorption, bonding Se with polymers or cathode electrolyte interphase (CEI) construction, and catalytic design to accelerate the conversion of LiPSe, different strategies for improving the utilization of Se have been evaluated and discussed. To address the inevitable loss of Se, prospects on inactive Se reactivation and Li protection are detailedly proposed and analyzed referring to the chemistry and corrosion science. Additionally, the perspectives on the future design and comprehensive parameter evaluations for the optimization of Li-Se batteries are recommended. This review comprehensively explains the causes and solutions of capacity fading and provides potential efforts for lifespan expansion of batteries, shedding light on the future development of Li-Se batteries. Keywords Lithium-selenium battery Shuttle effect Adsorption Catalysis Inactive Se reactivation Li protection 1 Introduction With increasingly severe energy demand and environmental issues, as well as the rapid development of electronic and electrical equipment, battery as a high-capacity energy storage device is urgently needed. In 1990, Sony Corporation launched graphite-based lithium-ion battery (LIB) to market, announcing the arrival of the battery age [1]. Since then, LIB has been widely applied in electronic equipment, electric tools, and electric vehicles due to its high energy, low self-discharge, absence of memory effect, wide operating temperature range, and long cycle lifespan [2]. However, the market puts forward high requirements for battery energy and safety. The theoretical specific capacity of electrode materials (e.g., LiCoO2: 278 mA h g−1), the security risks of electrolyte leakage, and the self-ignition of LIB are difficult to meet the future demand of high-performance portable electronic devices and electric vehicles [3]. The next-generation metallic battery, especially lithium-sulfur (Li-S) battery, has enabled the applications of novel-type electrodes. Notably, sulfur (S), as one of such emerging cathode materials, shows various merits, such as high theoretical capacity (1672 mA h g−1), low cost and environmental friendliness, which has been widely studied in recent years [4]. Nevertheless, the practical applications of Li-S batteries have been inhibited by several problems, including the low electronic conductivity of S, huge volume expansion from S to Li2S, and lithium polysulfides (LiPS) dissolution induced redox shuttle effect [5]. Selenium (Se), as another chalcogen element, has recently attracted enormous attention [6]. Compared to S (5 × 10−28 S m−1), Se has a much higher electrical conductivity (1 × 10−3 S m−1), which is beneficial for electron transportation in batteries. Moreover, the shuttle effect induced by soluble lithium polyselenides (LiPSe, Li2Se n , 4 ≤ n ≤ 8) in Li-Se battery is much weaker than that of LiPS in Li-S battery [7]. Li-Se battery has a comparable theoretical volumetric capacity (3253 mA h cm−3) to that of Li-S batteries (3467 mA h cm−3), which is one of the most important properties of miniaturized batteries for portable devices [8]. These advantages suggest that the Li-Se battery will be a promising energy storage device. The discharge/charge of Li-Se battery is based on the redox reaction between Se and Li (Fig. 1 a). In ether-based electrolytes, the discharging process can be derived into four stages: (1) the Se8-ring is lithiated to form long chain lithium polyselenides of Li2Se8; (2) Li2Se8 reduced to Li2Se n (n ≥ 4), leading the first reduction platform at the voltage of ∼2.1 V; (3) the long chain Li2Se n is reduced to Li2Se2. Here, the second reduction platform appears at the voltage of ∼2.0 V, and the capacity undergoes great increase; (4) Li2Se2 is finally reduced to Li2Se (Fig. 1b). The charging process is opposite to the discharging process from Li2Se back to Se. However, rapid capacity decay and safety problems of Li-Se batteries limit their entry into the market. Such issues are attributed to the loss of the active Se in cathode, the depletion of electrolytes, and deactivation of Li anode during battery operation [9]. Recently, considerable efforts have been devoted to addressing these problems of Li-Se batteries. The research statistics shown in Fig. 1(c) indicate that the number of research works on Li-Se batteries is growing exponentially. Several excellent review papers for the Li-Se battery have been published, mainly focusing on the design methods of cathode host materials, such as different types of materials, hierarchical dimensions, and heteroatom-doping [10–12]. In this work, considering the factors that caused these problems (i.e., how to reduce the loss of active Se), we classify these strategies: (1) high Se species retention by volume accommodation and blocking the transportation of soluble LiPSe to provide sufficient active materials; (2) accelerating rapid LiPSe conversion to maximize its utilization (Fig. 1d). However, there are always some Se species that participate in the solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) formation or are electrically isolated from the current collector to lose their activity (i.e., inactive Se). Therefore, achieving the reactivation of the inactive Se supplements a new perspective to further improve energy density of Li-Se batteries. Except for these efforts on the cathode, protecting Li metal anode to inhibit Li dendrites growth, reduce Li corrosion, construct a stable SEI and reactivate inactive Li are also very important for the lifespan and safety of the battery. In addition, all-solid-state electrolytes may achieve unexpected adaptability in Li-Se to suppress the shuttle effect of LiPSe. Moreover, the “one pot” strategy by integrating the commonality of the cathode and anode modification provides the possibility to solve cathode and anode problems at once. Notably, all the research is based on a deep understanding of the reaction mechanisms of the batteries, therefore advanced characterization support is necessary. In the end, the establishment of the evaluation criteria is indispensable for comprehensive evaluation of battery performance and selection of promising battery materials. We believe this work will provide theoretical and feasible strategy guidance for the future design of high performance Li-Se batteries and promote their practical applications. 2 High Se maintenance Se, as the active material in the Li-Se batteries, its utilization rate determines the capacity of the battery. However, due to the working mechanism of the Li-Se batteries, the discharge intermediates of soluble LiPSe are transferred from the cathode driven by the concentration and voltage difference between cathode and anode. Once the dissolved LiPSe comes into direct contact with Li, the Li2Se is produced on the surface of Li anode for their reaction. In this case, the Se species of Li2Se cannot turn back to cathode, inducing the loss of active Se materials. In addition, because of the alternating expansion and shrinkage in the operation, the cathode film generates cracks on its surface and finally peels off from cathode current collector. Thus, the quick capacity decay of the Li-Se batteries can be attributed to the continuous loss of active Se due to the cracks or peeling off of cathode, and shuttle effects of intermediates LiPSe. Therefore, maintaining high Se content in the cathode is a prerequisite for achieving high capacity of Li-Se batteries. To avoid active Se loss, the modification strategies can be carried out in two directions: (1) avoiding cracks and peeling off of active Se from cathode by alleviating volume expansion; (2) blocking the shuttling of LiPSe. 2.1 Avoiding volume expansion to reduce cracks and peeling off of active Se The content and utilization of Se are directly related to the energy density of the Li-Se battery. Because of the considerable mass density difference between Se and discharge products of Li2Se, the cathode undergoes volume expansion and shrinkage during discharging and charging, which leads to the cathode cracking and final peeling off. Designing high surface area Se nanoparticles and uniformly dispersing them into cathode host materials or constructing porous Se host materials could solve this problem well. In addition, the free-standing cathode and Li2Se cathode can alleviate the volume expansion to some extent. 2.1.1 Morphology modification of active Se and host materials Se nanoparticles with small particle size and high surface area could improve the cycle stability and specific capacity performance of Li-Se battery. That is beneficial from the accommodation of Se volume expansion to avoid or reduce the cracks and peeling off of active Se from cathode. In addition, porous small size Se particles provide more active reaction sites and shorten pathways of electrons and lithium ions (Li+), promoting the utilization of Se. The schematic diagram of modified Se particles is displayed in Fig. 2 (a). For instance, a kind of nanoporous Se (NP-Se) was synthesized with CaCO3 template by Liu et al. [14]. Compared with commercial Se particles (CP-Se, only 0.3 m2 g−1), the BET surface area of the NP-Se (40.9 m2 g−1) is enlarged obviously, which is beneficial to the expansion accommodation. The reversible capacity of the NP-Se achieved 206 mA h g−1 at the 20th cycle with Coulombic efficiency (CE) of 86%, which exhibited significant improvement compared with 60 mA h g−1 of CP-Se. Wang et al. fabricated a kind of Se nanowires with the help of anodic aluminum oxide (AAO) template [15]. After 50 cycles, the bulk Se electrode underwent 300% volume expansion and poor cycle stability. The Se nanowire cathode achieved three times higher discharge capacity than bulk Se due to less volume expansion. The Se particles with smaller size and higher surface area prolong the cycle life of the Li-Se batteries to some extent. However, the quick failure of capacity does not change (lifespan is usually limited to 50 cycles) since the advantages brought by the morphology modification will soon disappear by its conversion reaction mechanism. In addition, dispersing the Se particles into host materials has proved to be an effective strategy to solve the problem of volume expansion of the cathode. Fan et al. synthesized hollow Se nanospheres and encapsulated them within 3D graphene hydrogels [16] (Fig. 2b). With the protection coating layer, the capacity and stability of the battery were improved, delivering 343 mA h g−1 in the 50th cycle with CE of ∼97%. In order to tightly confine Se particles in cathode, Mukkabla et al. in-situ integrated the Se nanoparticles (NPs) with cetyltrimethylammonium bromide (CTAB) decorated multi-walled carbon nanotubes (MWCNTs) and fabricated Se NPs@CTAB-MWCNTs [17]. The Se NPs@CTAB-MWCNTs composite cathode delivered a high initial discharge capacity of 570.4 mA h g−1, and the capacity retained at 171.8 mA h g−1 at 0.5 C with CE of 99% after 500 cycles. Through the unique morphology design of high surface area Se particles, the electrochemical performance of Li-Se batteries has achieved obvious improvement. However, the expansion issue of crystalline Se still exists. Zhou et al. explored the different Se nanowires (NWs) states of amorphous (a-Se NWs), crystalline (c-Se NWs), and crystalline/amorphous (c/a-Se NW) on battery performance (Fig. 2c) [18]. As is shown in Fig. 2(d), the a-Se NWs have higher surface area than c-Se NWs. The a-Se NWs achieved the best performance compared to c/a-Se NW and c-Se NW, with an initial capacity of 755 mA h g−1 and reversible capacity of 350 mA h g−1 with CE of almost 100% after 100 cycles. The improved performance is due to the enhanced volume accommodation ability and abundant active sites in a-Se. Guided by this conclusion, loading amorphous Se in cathode is an ideal state for Li-Se batteries. Confining Se inside a porous is a simple and efficient method. The porous frameworks have large space and high pore volume for Se loading and expansion accommodation. In addition, the dispersed Se inside of the framework host prefers to stay in amorphous state, which is beneficial for the electrochemical reaction. Deng et al. synthesized hierarchically porous nitrogen-doped carbon (HPNC) with micro-, meso-, and macropores for Se host [19]. The Se in HPNC was in amorphous state (Fig. 2e), which efficiently accommodates large Se volume variation. In addition, Song et al. designed nitrogen-doped core-shell hierarchically porous carbon derived from ZIF-8 and ZIF-67 [20]. The porous structure greatly increases Se loading and buffers volume expansion. These corresponding Se/C composites exhibited an ultrahigh discharge specific capacity and cyclic stability (432 mA h g−1 after 200 cycles at 1 C with CE of 98%). No matter the design of Se nanoparticles or the construction of porous Se host materials, the purpose of all these strategies is to increase the contact between Se and the host material, which is beneficial to enlarge the reaction sites and provide the space for volume expansion. Until now, the efficient method is to disperse amorphous Se inside a porous rich host. However, the high mass Se loading is usually accompanied by the crystalline state of Se, which reduces the utilization of Se. Therefore, looking for novel methods or new host materials to load Se with amorphous state, high reactivity and utilization is the goal of future. 2.1.2 Constructing of free-standing electrodes The most common cathodes currently used in Li-Se battery is fabricated by coating the slurry consisting of active material, binder, and conductive material on metal current collector. Due to the expansion and shrinkage of cathode during battery operation, the coated film may peel off from current collector. Free-standing electrode is prepared by one step binding-free method. In this case, the problem of cathode film peeling off will disappear. In addition, the free-standing electrodes are usually rich in pores, which are beneficial to the cathode volume accommodation. More importantly, the free-standing electrode has good flexibility, which accommodates the stress inside the electrode. The highly flexible one-dimensional nanofiber/nanobelts are promising candidates for constructing free-standing cathodes. For example, Zeng et al. prepared a kind of porous carbon nanofibers (PCNFs) as the skeleton for the free-standing electrode by electrospinning the precursor solution of polyacrylonitrile (PAN) and triblock copolymer Pluronic F127 [21]. The flexible porous carbon nanofibers free-standing Se@PCNFs cathode exhibited excellent cycle stability and retained a reversible capacity of 516 mA h g−1 in the 900th cycle at the current of 0.5 A g−1. Even at 4 A g−1, a high capacity of 306 mA h g−1 was achieved. Cai et al. confined Se in hollow-core nitrogen-doped carbon (CN x ) nanobelts as a free-standing cathode material in Li-Se battery [22]. The free-standing electrode accommodated large volume expansion and promoted electron and ion transfer, at the same time provided physical adsorption for LiPSe, thereby generating high specific capacity, good rate capability, and cycle stability. As a layered structural material, graphene has good volume accommodation between its layers. In addition, graphene with the characteristics of easy filming, and rapid electrons/ions transportability, became an ideal candidate framework for free-standing cathode. Han et al. synthesized Se/MCN-RGO free-standing cathode material by embedding Se impregnated mesoporous carbon nanoparticles (Se/MCN) in reduced graphene oxide (GRO) sheets [23]. The layer structure free-standing Se/MCN-RGO with high Se loading of 62 wt% exhibited good volume change adaptability, exhibiting a high initial discharge capacity (655 mA h g−1) close to the theoretical value at 0.1 C and an ultra-long cycle stability, with a capacity retention of 61% after 1300 cycles at 1 C. Moreover, He et al. synthesized a three-dimensional graphene-CNT@Se (3DG-CNT@Se) aerogel by combining the advantages of CNTs and graphene (Fig. 2f) [24]. The 3D mesoporous conductive network provides channels for highly efficient electron transfer and ion diffusion, and the hierarchical structure within prevents fast dissolution of LiPSe and suppresses volume expansion of Se in charge/discharge process. The main methods to achieve free-standing cathode are filtration and electrospinning of nanofibers, graphene and their mixtures. Electrospinning is an ideal technology for large-scale fabrication of the free-standing Se cathode. However, the equipment price is high, and large-scale production is still limited. Achieving uniform surface and high strength of large area free-standing film with high Se loading is the direction of efforts. The battery performance with different Se cathodes is summarized in Fig. 2(g) and Table 1 . Compared with commercial bulk Se, Se particle modification with high surface area indeed improved the specific capacity. However, the increase is limited due to these particles are still large crystalline state and the morphological advantages disappear quickly due to the conversion mechanism. Confining these modified Se particles with carbon materials increases electrical conductivity and volume expansion accommodation capacity of the cathode, which contributes to the Se utilization. Compared with crystalline Se, amorphous Se supports high volume accommodation and reaction sites. Loading Se in porous carbon materials and free-standing host, the Li-Se batteries achieved high specific capacity and arch long lifespan, indicating the most promising method for Se cathode modification. 2.1.3 Substituting Se with Li2Se cathode Large volume expansion exists in Se during discharging and charging. Some researchers look for its substitution, such as Li2Se used as active material in Li-Se battery. Li2Se undergoes 40% volume shrinkage rather than 80% volume expansion of Se. The relieved volumetric effect of Li2Se cathode makes the cathode more stable. Most attractively, using prelithiated Li2Se as the active material promotes the construction of Li-free anode battery configuration, further increasing the energy density of Li-Se batteries. However, the problems of low conductivity of Li2Se and the shuttle effect of LiPSe still exist. All the strategies to improve the Se cathode, including the porous structure design, heteroatoms doping, and polar transition metal compounds, are suitable for Li2Se cathode. For example, Wu et al. embedded Li2Se nanoparticles into a conductive carbon matrix [25]. The capacity of pure Li2Se nanoparticles exhibited a rapid drop, arriving at less than 100 mA h g L i 2 S e - 1 (based on the active mass of Li2Se) in 100 cycles. By coating with a carbon shell protection layer on nanosized-Li2Se in carbon matrix (C-Li2Se), the obtained composite (C-Li2Se@C) achieved a stable capacity of ∼300 mA h g L i 2 S e - 1 . Notably, unlike Se, the active Li2Se loading cannot be achieved by diffusing into small pores of host materials or in-situ produced. The prelithiated Li2Se nanoparticles prefer accumulation, which is not good for their uniform dispersion. In this case, the advantages brought by the less shrinkage of Li2Se will disappear. Moreover, the production of Li2Se is difficult and high price. There is a long way to go to solve these problems. In summary, the peeling off Se from cathode can be handled with the methods of accommodation Se particle expansion by morphology modification, application of free-standing cathode, or introducing less volume expansion Li2Se as active material of the battery. The carbon porous hosts and free-standing Se cathodes are the most promising strategies to reduce volume expansion and achieve high Se loading. In addition, the integrity of Se cathode can be achieved by binder modification. Inspired by Li-S batteries, the binders with the characteristics of high chemical and mechanical stability, high adhesion ability to current collector and Se particles, and high interaction between binder and Se species will be ideal candidates for Li-Se batteries, such as ionic cross-linked sodium alginate [26], cross-linked polyacrylamide (c-PAM) [27], cross-linked gelatin (GN), and boric acid (BA) [28]. Without bulk Se loss in the cathode, the battery lifespan is greatly improved. In addition, the high Se maintenance in the cathode provides conditions for high reaction sites and high stability of the Li-Se battery. 2.2 Blocking the shuttling of LiPSe Blocking the shuttling of LiPSe is an efficient strategy to reduce the loss of Se species, which can be realized by adsorption of the LiPSe. The adsorption can be implemented in different steps during the battery working, including dissolution and diffusion in cathode, transportation in electrolyte and passing through the separator. According to the interaction between LiPSe and host materials, the adsorption can be derived into physical adsorption and chemisorption. In addition, construction of a stable cathode electrolyte interphase (CEI) layer and Se bonding with host polymer materials can also efficiently block the shuttling of LiPSe. The strategies of the blocking the shuttling LiPSe are shown in Fig. 3 (a). 2.2.1 Enhancing adsorption of LiPSe The physical confinement effects (van der Waals adsorption) can inhibit the diffusion of dissolved LiPSe. The porous structure and pore size of Se host materials have a great influence on the physical adsorption of LiPSe [29]. Carbon materials are popularly used as Se hosts due to the advantages of high electric conductivity and easily achieved porous structure. For example, Jun et al. prepared micropores-rich monodisperse carbon spheres (RFCS) as Se host material [30]. The introduced Se occupied the pores of RFCS and stayed in an amorphous state. The Li-Se battery based on RFCS/Se-50 (Se loading 50 wt%) composite exhibited a high reversible capacity of 643.9 mA h g−1 in the 100th cycle at 0.2 C. However, carbon spheres only with micropores are not good for the transportation of electrolytes (i.e., Li+). Park et al. synthesized well-developed micropores and mesopores carbon microspheres (Fig. 3b) to accelerate conversion reaction of LiPSe [31]. The carbon/Se electrode exhibited initial charge capacities of 632 mA h g−1 and a stable reversible capacity of 582 mA h g−1 after 500 cycles at a current density of 0.5 A g−1. Even at a high current density of 2.0 A g−1, the capacity maintained at 343 mA h g−1 after 2000 cycles, which is much higher than similar carbon microspheres with solely micropores. Carbon nanotubes (CNTs) have hollow tubes inside to provide space for Se loading. To block the shuttling of LiPSe, Balakumar et al. synthesized Tube-in-Tube carbon (TTC) material with assistance of SiO2 as a hard template [32]. The MWCNTs (core) backbone provided the facile electron transfer pathway, while the surrounding porous carbon (shell) prevented the loss of active material. High specific surface area porous carbon host materials benefit Se accommodation and LiPSe capture. Liu et al. introduced more micropores by activating carbon nanofibers (MCNF) with KOH [33]. The obtained host displays the highly desirable characteristics of abundant porous nanostructure, interconnected channel structure, and high specific surface area, and achieved superior electrochemical performance in Li-Se battery. Zhang et al. synthesized porous carbon nanosheets (CNS) by calcination of potassium citrate for Se loading [34]. The optimal Se/CNSs composite achieved a reversible capacity of 672 mA h g−1 and remained at 376 mA h g−1 after 1000 cycles at 0.5 C. The superior electrochemical performance was attributed to the rich content of micro/mesopores, nanoplate structure and a high graphitization degree of the carbon host. Li et al. synthesized a series of Se/G-xCNTs (x: content of CNTs, wt%) composites as cathode material for Li-Se battery [35]. All these composites possessed micropores size of 1–2 nm and mesopores size of 2–4 nm. Compared with pure CNTs or graphene host, the optimized Se/G-18 CNTs cathode delivered a much higher initial capacity of 575 mA h g−1 at 0.5 A g−1 and a retained capacity of 479 mA h g−1 at 2.0 A g−1. The achieved good rate capability and cycle stability were due to the 3D hierarchically porous framework and excellent electron transfer. Dai et al. synthesized 3D hierarchically porous carbon structure with a high level of micro-, meso- and macro-level porosities [36]. The hierarchical electrode architectures enabled high loading Se of 57.5 wt%, tight encapsulation of both the small and long-chain LiPSe species, suppression of continuous SEI formation, and enhanced transposition of electrolyte. Li et al. synthesized a 3D ordered hierarchically porous carbon with tunable pore size [37]. The optimized cathode material following the concept of the generalized Murray’s law maximizes the performance of advanced Li-Se battery. Porous carbon host materials can suppress the dissolution of LiPSe intermediates by physical adsorption. However, the weak interaction between the nonpolar carbon materials and the polar LiPSe is insufficient to capture the soluble LiPSe. In addition to adjusting the porosity of the carbon materials, improving the polarity of the host materials is another effective solution to addressing the shuttle of LiPSe. Heteroatoms, such as O, N, and S elements, have a higher electronegativity than that of C, and thus have a strong interaction with LiPSe, known as “chemisorption”. Carbonization of N, P, or O-rich precursor to form heteroatoms doped carbon is one of the simplest and most common methods. Jia et al. synthesized chitosan derived porous carbon framework (CPC) for Li-Se battery [38]. The Se-50.2/CPC (Se loaded 50.2 wt%) composite cathode delivered a reversible capacity of 673.1 mA h g−1 in the 2nd cycle and maintained at 633.9 mA h g−1 after 100 cycles at 0.1 C. Zhao et al. synthesized a N and O dually-doped hierarchically porous carbon (HDHPC) utilizing polydopamine as the precursor [39]. Pyrrolic-N and ketonic-O co-doped carbon possessed a strong interaction to Li2Se with the binding energy of −3.04 eV (Fig. 3c), which is much higher than that of pure carbon (−0.96 eV). The result indicates that heteroatom doping (N, O) can effectively enhance the interaction between LiPSe guests and carbon host. Consequently, the composite cathode delivered a good electrochemical performance with a stable reversible capacity of 545 mA h g−1 at 0.5 C after 1500 cycles (Fig. 3d). Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), rich in pores and heteroatoms (O and N), are important precursor materials to produce heteroatom-doped carbon [40]. N-doped graphitic C-Co scaffold (C-Co-N) derived from ZIF-67 was synthesized by He’s group and used for the impregnation of Se [41]. In addition, Al-MOF [42] and Ni-MOF [43] were also N-doped porous carbons precursors. Many other heteroatoms doped carbon materials were synthesized from different raw precursors, such as polypyrrole [44], polyaniline [45], amino acid-rich gelatin [46], cyanuric chloride [47], melamine [48], pyrrole [49], polyacrylonitrile [50], etc. Notably, carbon materials derived from heteroatoms-rich biomass, such as fruit peel [51], cereal shell [52], plant straw [53], silk [54], etc., have been widely used in Li-Se batteries. Since all these carbon precursors are rich in heteroatoms, the synthesized heteroatoms-doped carbon materials are enabled easily and efficiently. Heteroatom-doped carbon framework materials can enhance the adsorption to LiPSe, while being limited by the number of doping sites. Polar nanostructures rich in O, N, S/Se elements, such as metal oxide, metal sulfides/selenides and some conductive polymers, are beneficial to inhibit the shuttle effect by strong chemisorption with soluble LiPSe [55]. For example, Ye et al. coated 5 nm MnO2 nanoparticles on the surface of ZIF-67@Se to form a MOF@Se@MnO2 composite [56]. The obtained MOF@Se@MnO2 sandwich structure provided more active sites for tethering the Se to reduce the shuttle effect and the dissolution of LiPSe in the electrolyte. MXenes is a compound composed of layered transition metal nitrides, carbides, sulfides, or halides. Jayan et al. used MXenes as an effective LiPSe immobilizer for Li-Se batteries [57]. In Fig. 3(e), compared with graphene, the electron transfer from the LiPSe to Ti3C2O2 increases, leading to stronger chemical interactions between LiPSe and Ti3C2O2. In Fig. 3(f), the calculated Li2Se n adsorption strength provided by S and O terminated Ti3C2 (i.e., Ti3C2S2 and Ti3C2O2) is stronger than the commonly used ether-based electrolyte (DME and DOL), indicating the effective suppression of the Li2Se n shuttling. For different MXenes, the adsorption energy in Ti3C2S2 and Ti3C2O2 are higher than other MXenes and graphene, demonstrating stronger chemical interactions of Li2Se n with S and O terminated surfaces. In addition, the strong interfacial interaction between metal selenide (Ag2Se, CoSe2, etc.) and LiPSe enables the LiPSe to be effectively anchored on the surface of the metal selenide [58]. Moreover, Luo et al. encapsulated Se/C composites in ultra-thin Ni(OH)2 nanosheets to form Se/C-Ni(OH)2 cathode [59]. Due to the ultra-thin Ni(OH)2 nanosheets forming a strong protective layer outside of the Se/C composites, the dissolution and shuttle effect of LiPSe were reduced greatly. Wang et al. developed PANI@Se/C-G composite by encapsulating polyaniline (PANI)-coated Se/C nanocomposite into graphene sheets [60]. A high specific capacity of 588.7 mA h g−1 was achieved at 0.2 C after 200 cycles due to the polar groups of PNAI. No matter the physical adsorption of pores or chemisorption of heteroatoms and polar nanoparticles, the soluble LiPSe was greatly suppressed. Until now, complete inhibition of the shuttle of LiPSe has not yet been realized. For the LiPSe that has already diffused out of the cathode, the remedies can be carried out in separator or interface to block their continuous shuttling to the anode side. Inserting an isolation layer between the separator and the cathode can block the diffusion of LiPSe and greatly improve the performance of the Li-Se battery. The thickness, affinity to the separator, and stability during the operation of interface layer should be given deep research to achieve an ideal electrochemical performance of Li-Se batteries. 2.2.2 Stable CEI layer construction LiPSe escaping from the cathode will diffuse to Li anode under the concentration gradient, where it reacts with Li, resulting in a decrease in LiPSe concentration, which in turn accelerates the loss of LiPSe in Se cathode. Forming a dense and uniform cathode electrolyte interphase (CEI) on the surface of the cathode is an effective method to protect Se species from contacting the Li anode because the CEI layer maintains Li+ permeability while preventing the transportation of LiPSe. The reaction mechanism of the CEI and SEI is shown in Fig. 4 (a). When the Fermi level of anode (μ A) is above the lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO), the electrolyte will be reduced to form SEI. Likewise, a passivation layer (i.e., CEI) will be produced when Fermi level of cathode (μ C) is below the highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO) [61]. Generally, the electrochemical potential of S/Se cathode is inside the stability window of the electrolyte. However, due to the defects and host materials in the cathode, the Fermi level will be out of the electrolyte stability window, leading to the production of CEI [62]. Same with SEI, the CEI is formed in the Li+ insertion process and can be described as a mosaic model with an inorganic inner layer and an organic out layer (Fig. 4b) [63,64]. Modification of the electrolyte formulation is an implementable method to get an ideal CEI layer, including additives, solvents, and Li-salts. For example, Zhou et al. added 10% fluoroethylene carbonate (FEC) into carbonate-based electrolyte (EC and DMC) containing difluoro(oxalato)borate (LiDFOB) [65]. By addition of FEC in the electrolyte, a highly stable and Li+ permeable solid interphase layer formed on both Li anode and Se/microporous carbon cathode. The CEI layer avoids the continuous inverse reaction of LiPSe with carbonate-based electrolytes and reduces the generation of Li dendrites. Similarly, Lee et al. added FEC additive to the ether-based electrolyte to form a stable CEI layer on the cathode, as is shown in Fig. 4(c) [66]. Because of the greatly reduced reactivity with LiPSe, the FEC additive enables stable CEI in regular ether-based electrolytes. In addition, other additives, such as LiNO3 [67], lithium bis (oxalato) borate (LiBOB) [68], tris(trimethylsilyl) borate (TMSB) [69], LiN3 [70], LiI [71], show stable CEI film-forming ability in Li-S batteries, which provides guidance for the selection of additives of Li-Se batteries. Using fluorinated organic solvents in the formulation of the electrolytes can reduce the solubility of LiPSe, and form a LiF-rich CEI. For instance, Xu et al. replaced the electrolyte solvent of DME with hydrofluoroether (HFE) in the electrolyte of 1 M LiTFSI/DOL + DME (1:1, by volume) [72]. The LiF-rich CEI layer was formed on the surface of the cathode due to the high nucleophilicity of HFE, which prevented the attack of solvent molecules toward Se–S, thus switching of (de)lithiation reaction pathway from solid-liquid-solid to solid-solid compared to the traditional ether-based electrolyte. The LiTFSI is considered the most suitable Li salt in Li-S and Li-Se batteries. For Li-S batteries, increasing Li salt concentration renders the less number of free solvent molecules and boosts electrolyte viscosity, which thus results in a decreased solubility of LiPS and stable CEI. At extremely high LiTFSI concentration, all solvents coordinate to Li+ and form unique contact ion pairs or aggregates, exhibiting an extremely low solubility for LiPS (Fig. 4d) [73]. The solubility of LiPS decreases with the increase of the concentration of the Li salt of the electrolyte (Fig. 4e) [74]. This bifunctional “solvent-in-salt” electrolyte benefits the high CE and long-term cyclability. This high concentration electrolyte method may be extended to Li-Se batteries. An artificial CEI layer between the separator and cathode can block the diffusion of LiPSe and greatly improve the performance of the Li-Se battery, which can be achieved by directly adding an external artificial interlayer between cathode and separator or coating separator with functional materials. The artificial CEI should possess some common properties, such as high electrical conductivity, superior ion conductivity, and confinement/adsorpability of LiPSe. CNTs and graphene meet all the above requisites and are good choices as interlayer materials for Li-Se batteries. For example, Peng et al. placed CNTs membrane between the reduced graphene oxide encapsulated Se (Se@RGO) cathode and separator to serve as the barrier layer (Fig. 4f) [75]. Li et al. introduced CNTs interlayer on the cathode side of a Celgard 2400 separator to form a CNTs interlayer-coated separator [35]. The CNTs interlayer functions as a artificial CEI to restrict the diffusion of LiPSe, thereby enhancing the cycling performance of the battery (Fig. 4g). In addition, Fang et al. coated graphene on the surface of separator and the cell capacity was up to 331 mA h g−1 after 1000 cycles at 0.5 C [76]. Xia et al. prepared a Se cathode having an alternating of multi-walled carbon nanotubes (MWCNTs)/graphene barrier layer and active layer [77]. The MWCNTs/graphene interlayer served as LiPSe blocking barrier and highly conductive current collector. The strong LiPSe trapping ability of the artificial CEI layer contributed high specific capacity of battery (508 mA h g−1) after 300 cycles even in a high Se loading condition (4.5 mg cm−2). In order to enhance the adsorption strength to prevent the diffusion of LiPSe, Gu et al. prepared an ultra-light, conductive, and free-standing N, S co-doped graphene N, S-G film, which functioned as a current collector and simultaneously as a barrier layer to LiPSe [78]. The conductive N, S-G film effectively limits the shuttle effect by providing physical/chemical adsorption to LiPSe. Some metal oxides have strong adsorption to LiPSe, which can also function as interlayer materials. For example, Mukkabla et al. loaded tungsten oxide (WO3) interlayer on the separator to further avoid the problems of dissolution and shuttling effect of LiPSe [79]. The Li-WO3@Separator/Se-AAC battery showed an initial charge capacity of 808 mA h g−1 with CE of 91.1% and 510 mA h g−1 after 100 cycles with CE of 97% (Fig. 4h). In addition, MOFs rich in pores and heteroatoms are ideal materials for artificial CEI to suppress the shuttle effect of LiPSe. For example, Bai et al. presented a MOF-based battery separator to mitigate the shuttling problem [80]. The small pore size of MOF-based separator (approximately 9 Å) played the role of an efficient ionic sieve towards LiPS migrating to the anode. The CEI generated by electrolyte formulation is easy to implement, while there are problems in formula screening and increased costs. The introduced artificial CEI has a significant blocking effect on LiPSe shuttle. However, the function of the artificial CEI is not durable in the long cycle process, and the introduced inert interlayer reduces the energy density of the battery. Research on the preparation of new, high-efficiency, and lightweight CEI will be a direction of efforts. 2.2.3 Bonding Se with polymers as cathode host materials The diffusion of soluble small molecular LiPSe is unavoidable for Se active material, so riveting Se species in cathode by polymer chain is a feasible strategy. Inspired by Li-S batteries, bonding Se with polymers to form Se-rich polymer will be a promising strategy to avoid the shuttle effect of LiPSe. In Li-S battery, S-rich polymers have been explored as cathode materials and shown unique properties, such as easy synthesis, structural tunability, and precise active sites. In a pioneering work, Chung et al. utilized elemental S and 1,3-diisopropenylbenzene (DIB) as co-monomers to synthesize S-rich polymers (poly(S-r-DIB)) by the inverse vulcanization method, as shown in Fig. 5 (a) [81]. The inverse vulcanization chemistry elemental remains S in a processable polymeric form but retains its electrochemical activity. The cyclic voltammetry (CV) result in Fig. 5(b) confirmed that poly(S-r-DIB) copolymers exhibited very similar electrochemical behavior to that of S8. Different from the S cathode, the S atoms in S-polymers are tightly bound with polymers, so the shuttle effect disappears during battery operation. Se-rich polymer of phenyl diselenide (PDSe) was synthesized by Fu’s group. However, the theoretical capacity of PDSe battery was calculated to be 171.7 mA h g−1, and the solubility problem of PDSe makes it unsuitable as the cathode material. In order to reduce the solubility of organo-diselenide in electrolyte and obtain a high capacity of the battery, PDSe-S and PDSe-S2 were synthesized via the addition reaction of PDSe and S [82]. Compared with the low initial capacity of PDSe (118 mA h g−1), PDSe-S and PDSe-S2 exhibited higher initial capacities of 252 and 330 mA h g−1, respectively. Subsequently, phenyl selenosulfide (PhS-SePh) was synthesized by an exchange reaction between phenyl disulfide and diselenide [83]. PhS-SePh performed better kinetics and much better cycle stability than PhS-SPh and PhSe-SePh for its higher entropy of the mixture and thus lower Gibbs free energy. The existence of Se in the S-rich polymer decreases the capacity of the battery, but enhances the electronic conductivity and improves the transportation of Li+. Zhou et al. synthesized a Se-doped organic polymer material (PDATtSSe) and obtained an improved volumetric capacity and CE (almost 100%) [84]. Compared to pure S-rich polymer electrodes, the doping of Se significantly enhanced the electronic conductivity of battery electrodes, and the formation of long-chain LiPS was restricted. The inverse vulcanization method has been extended to the synthesis of hybrid organic-inorganic S-Se co-polymers. Dong et al. introduced SeS2 into the polymeric S and obtained S-rich polymeric selenium sulfides (S-SeS2-DIB, DIB: 1,3-diisopropenylbenzene) [85]. The divinyl functional groups of DIB were chemically cross-linked with S/SeS2 chain radicals through a ring-opening polymerization, as shown in Fig. 5(c). The newly formed bonds of C–S, C–Se, and S–Se in S-SeS2-DIB copolymers effectively alleviated the shuttle effects of LiPS/LiPSe, achieving a higher reversible capacity of 650 mA h g−1 with CE of 99.5% than that of pure S-DIB (580 mA h g−1 with CE of 98%) after 100 cycles (Fig. 5d). In S-Se co-polymers, the short S and Se chains in hybrid S-Se co-polymers are chemically capped by organic groups, which make long LiPS and LiPSe difficult to form in the following cycling process. In this case, the shuttle effect could be greatly decreased. The S-Se co-polymers play a good performance in inhibiting the shuttle effect. However, the Se/S active materials loading inside the polymer can hardly to reach a very high level (50–70 wt%) and the electronic conductivity of the polymer is also limited (improvement with conductive carbon, the active content of cathode will be lower). Such factors reduce the capacity and energy density of the Li-Se battery to a relativity low value, which is difficult to achieve the goal of high energy density batteries. Therefore, improving the active S/Se content in the polymer and increasing its conductivity may further enlarge the energy density of the battery. The strong adsorption of the polar sites porous host materials, and chemical bonding of Se/S polymer can prevent the diffusion of LiPSe out of the cathode host materials, which benefits in high capacity and good stability of the battery. In addition, the dense and inorganic rich CEI could efficiently block the diffusion of LiPSe that are released from the cathode. Combining Se/S polymer and traditional porous carbon host with an inorganic CEI may be a promising method to achieve high capacity and high stability of Li-Se/S batteries. 3 Acceleration the electrochemical kinetics of LiPSe High Se maintenance is the prerequisite for high energy density Li-Se battery, and achieving the high utilization of Se ensures the output energy of the battery. The discharging process of Li-Se battery undergoes conversion reaction from Se to Li2Se with the intermediate soluble LiPSe as redox mediator. Once the soluble LiPSe cannot realize quick conversion at high kinetics, the unreacted LiPSe suffers accumulation and diffuses to react with Li anode. Thus, accelerating the reaction kinetics of LiPSe conversion is an efficient method to reduce the loss of active Se, which also benefits Li anode protection. Introducing catalytic intermediates to the reaction system can accelerate the reaction kinetics, thereby inhibiting the shuttle effects of Li-Se batteries. According to the phase state of the reaction intermediate and catalyst, the catalysis can be divided into heterogeneous and homogeneous reaction systems (Fig. 6 a). 3.1 Heterogeneous reaction system catalysis The LiPSe is soluble in electrolyte and their conversion is in liquid phase. In a heterogeneous reaction system, the catalyst is usually in solid state. In this case, the LiPSe conversion is accelerated with the help of solid catalysis, including the steps of the LiPSe diffusion to the surface of solid catalyst, interaction adsorption, surficial reaction, desorption and diffusion back to liquid electrolyte. The chemical reaction is a process comprising the breakage of previous bonds and subsequent rebuilding of new bonds. The influence of catalysts on the bonds of LiPSe in the processes of diffusion, adsorption, and surface interaction is relevant to their catalytic ability. It is popularly recommended that the surface interaction is the limiting step of the LiPSe conversion. For heterogeneous catalytic reaction systems, uniformly dispersed and rich catalytic sites of catalyst shorten the diffusion pathway of LiPSe. Moreover, the strong adsorption of LiPSe to catalyst guarantees their tight contact. Besides the adsorption of the LiPSe, it is proved that polar compounds also catalyze the chemical reaction of LiPSe conversion. Some transition metal compounds (oxides, nitrides, selenides, sulfides, etc.) are considered to be the proper catalysts to accelerate kinetics of the reaction. Wu et al. synthesized hollow spherical α-MoO3 used for both adsorption and catalysis of LiPSe [86]. From the Li2Se6 solution adsorption experiment in Fig. 6(b), the solution with α-MoO3 changed to colorless after adsorption, suggesting that the α-MoO3 has enhanced interaction with LiPSe. The bifunctional catalysis and strong adsorption of α-MoO3 led to the lower overpotential during charge/discharge process, as shown in Fig. 6(c). Wang et al. proved that the strong adsorption was the premise of the next-step LiPS conversion. [87]. By adding CoSe2 catalyst, the bond length of S–S in Li2S4 and S–Li in Li2S becomes longer due to the strong adsorption between the CoSe2 substrate and LiPS. As is shown in Fig. 6(d), the bifunctional catalyst of anion N-doping CoSe2 composites (N-CoSe2) more effectively weakens the S–S bridged bond. Therefore, Li2S4 is easily broken and finally gradually converted to Li2S. As for the charging process, the Li2S is also easily converted back to S due to the weakened Li–S bond undergoing a lower barrier to form LiS– and Li–. The catalysis of CoSe2 is also suitable for Li-Se batteries. Yang et al. applied the CoSe2-porous carbon (CoSe2-PC) to Li-Se battery and explored its function on LiPSe [88]. The CoSe2 served as an effective electro-catalyst and dynamically facilitated the redox reaction kinetics of LiPSe and suppressed the dissolution of Li2Se n intermediates into the electrolyte. Se@CoSe2-PC achieved a high reversible capacity of 408 mA h g−1 with CE of 100% at the current density of 1 C after 100 cycles. Xiao et al. synthesized a series of two-dimensional (2D) selenides (TiSe2, VSe, VSe2, CrSe, FeSe, CoSe, NbSe2, MoSe2, InSe, SnSe, SnSe2, and WSe2) and analyzed their anchoring function and redox reaction kinetics for LiPS/S8 [89]. As shown in Fig. 6(e), all the 2D selenides promoted the LiPS/S8 conversion by decreasing reaction barrier, proving their catalytic effect on reaction. Among these 2D selenides, CoSe and SnSe achieved the best performance. Strong adsorption of polar particles to LiPS is helpful in suppressing the shuttle effect and catalyzing the reaction conversion. However, it does not mean that the stronger the adsorption, the higher the electrochemical performance will be [90]. Cui et al. proved that the moderate interaction of polar particles with LiPS should be considered in cathode materials [91]. As shown in Fig. 6(f), the strong interaction between introduced polar particles and LiPS weakens the Li–S and S–S bonds and even induces their breakage, which leads S to lose its electrochemical activity. In addition, Tao et al. fabricated various metal-oxides nanoparticles (MgO, Al2O3, CeO2, La2O3, and CaO) to be anchored on porous carbon nanoflakes [92]. MgO, with a medium adsorption strength to Li2S8, was recognized as one of the most potential catalysts for Li-S battery. Tao et al. analyzed the adsorption strength of intermediates (oxygen atom) on different transition metal oxide [93]. The 2p orbital of atomic oxygen is hybridized with the highest occupied d-states of the transition metal oxide, and the low filling of antibonding (i.e., Fermi level lower than antibonding states) is related to the strong adsorption of the intermediate on transition metal oxide (Fig. 6g). Thereby, adjusting the highest occupied d-states of transition metal oxides can realize the adjusting of the adsorption strength, achieving optimized catalysis to the reaction system. Han et al. confirmed that the less filling of antibonding (the d-p orbital hybridization between transition metal atom and LiPS) leads to strong adsorption of LiPS by analyzing a series of single atomic transition metal catalysts [94]. Although the rule is derived from the Li-S battery, due to the very similar properties of Se to S, it will provide guidance for Li-Se battery. In order to adjust a suitable binding energy for LiPSe adsorption and desorption, Li et al. introduced rutile (rTiO2) to the TiO2 and TiN catalytic composite to weaken its overall adsorption to LiPSe. The obtained aTiO2/rTiO2/TiN@C/Se cathode delivered good cycle stability and high rate capability [95]. Heterostructured catalysts were applied in Li-S batteries due to their synergistic functions in the conversion of LiPS. For instance, for TiO2-Ni3S2 heterostructure catalyst, the strong adsorption of TiO2 to LiPS ensures their tight contact, while Ni3S2 catalyzes LiPS conversion [96]. More heterostructured catalysts, such as VTe2@MgO [97], MoN-VN [98], and NiO-NiCo2O4 [99], were synthesized and have displayed their synergistic functions in Li-S batteries. A heterostructured catalyst of NiSe2/Ni2Co/CoSe2 was fabricated and used in Li-Se battery [100]. The fabricated heterointerface of the heterostructured catalyst performed accelerated conversion of LiPSe by quick transfer of electrons and Li+. Notably, like the positive electrode materials of lithium-ion batteries, the destruction of the phase structure leads to the loss of functionality [101], especially the weakening of the catalytic effect of the catalysts. The stability of the catalysts should be considered during battery operation. Liu et al. synthesized 1T-MoS2 by converting the phase structure from 2H MoS2. The phase-transition-free 1T-MoS2 ensures the stability of the catalyst while also increasing the interlayer spacing to provide better adsorption and catalytic sites [102]. In addition, single atom catalysts are also workable in Li-Se batteries due to their maximum atom utilization efficiency, homogenous active sites, and unique reaction mechanism [103]. The density-functional theory (DFT) calculation indicated that the reaction with single Co atom catalyst proposed lower Gibbs free energy due to the enlarged distance of Li-Se of LiPSe, as shown in Fig. 6(h) [104], revealing the catalytic function of single Co atoms. Inspired by the regulation of transition metal single atoms of LiPS, optimized transition metal atoms can be selected to achieve the best catalytic function for the conversion of LiPSe. In conclusion, the heterogeneous catalyst function can be maximized by enlarging the interface contact with a large surface area and proper adsorption strength to match the breaking and regeneration of bonds of LiPSe. 3.2 Homogeneous reaction system catalysis In heterogeneous catalysis system, the catalytic reaction undergoes on the surface of solid catalysts by diffusing the LiPS/LiPSe. Different from heterogeneous catalysis, homogeneous catalysts are soluble in the electrolyte. In this case, the LiPSe has its conversion in a short pathway distance without the diffusion of LiPSe, thereby inhibiting the shuttle effect of the battery. Until now, most of the homogeneous catalysis is realized by the soluble redox mediators. Aurbach group found that only the redox mediators with higher redox potential than the original redox (i.e., LiPS) have catalytic function to the operation of Li-S battery (Fig. 7 a) [105]. The deceased Li2S oxidation energy barrier benefits from the catalytic redox mediators (Fig. 7b), which prevents the continuous consumption of electrolyte under excessively high charge operating conditions. The other redox mediators of cobaltocene, decamethylferrocene, diphenyl diselenide (DPDSe), nickel chloride dimethoxyethane adduct (NiDME), quinone-based redox mediators, etc., performed good catalytic ability in Li2S decomposition and oxidation. The working mechanism of redox mediators in Li-S is also suitable for Li-Se batteries. Xie et al. explored the redox mediators of 1,4-benzenedithiol (1,4-BDT) and benzeneselenol (PhSeH) in the tuning of the electrochemical behavior of Li-Se battery [106]. As Fig. 7(c) shows, the additive redox mediators react with Li2Se and the soluble products in the electrolyte avoid the high energy barrier of sluggish solid-liquid surface reaction but with a much easier liquid-liquid homogeneous transformation without the generation of LiPSe. However, the soluble redox mediators also have the problem of shuttle effect by their diffusion and contact with highly active Li anode. Focus on this issue, Zhang’s group designed a semi-immobilized redox mediators by co-polymerized small imide molecules redox mediators with poly(ethylene oxide)-poly(propylene oxide) (polyether) chains (i.e., PIPE) [107]. The small imide molecules as redox mediators regulated the redox of sulfide species, and the co-polymer design relieves the shuttle effect of the additive redox mediators (Fig. 7d). The Li-S battery with PIPE as an RM achieved a high and stable capacity of 860 mA h g−1 at 0.1 C after 50 cycles with a high sulfur loading (Fig. 7e). The conversion of LiPSe maybe accelerates with the help of the introduced redox catalysts. Flow batteries, as a typical device that uses redox mediators to store energy, can provide guidance for the selection of redox mediators in Li-Se batteries [108]. However, the introduction of reaction intermediates is usually accompanied by severe self-discharge problems in the battery. Looking for suitable redox mediators of homogeneous reaction systems that can catalyze the reaction and overcome the self-discharge behavior is meaningful for the development of Li-Se batteries. In conclusion, the strategies for capacity decay caused by the reduced active Se species of the cathode are summarized and discussed. First, the Se active particles remain inside the cathode without cracks and peeling off. In addition, the soluble LiPSe is tightly confined in the cathode host framework by strong adsorption and accelerated LiPSe conversion by catalysts to avoid shuttle effect. For the LiPSe that has already diffused from cathode, a stable CEI interlayer between cathode and separator can further block their transportation. By the above step-by-step method for high Se activation, the capacity and cycle stability of Li-Se battery can achieve significant improvements. For the two main strategies of high retention and accelerating the LiPSe conversion kinetics, the latter may be the key point to achieving the high energy density commercial Li-Se battery. That is because the high Se retention will be destroyed following the increased accumulation of Se species in their low conversion kinetics condition. Towards the energy density up to 350 Wh kg−1, the S conversion rate should be at least 60% and higher for Se [109]. 4 Future prospects High performance Li-Se battery can be achieved by Se cathode modification. In addition, to further increase the performance of the battery, more prospective works can be carried out on the inactive Se reactivation, Li anode protection, and all-solid-state electrolytes. Especially, the “one pot” strategy can be simultaneously operated in cathode and anode due to their commonality modification methods. Moreover, the advanced characterization technologies and the evaluated parameters on the battery performance are urgently needed for optimizing battery. 4.1 The inactive Se reactivation High Se maintenance ensures the high reaction possibility of the active material, and the high reaction kinetics improves the utilization rate of Se, which greatly decreases the production of inactive Se. However, the active materials of Se and Li2Se cannot achieve complete conversion in the discharge/charge process, which is attributed to the cutting off of the electron transportation from the current collector to the isolated active material. In addition, some Se species participate in the generation of SEI, losing the activation in the following discharge/charge process. Achieving inactive Se reactivation becomes a promising strategy for high energy density Li-Se batteries. Researchers pay attention to inactive material reactivation. At present, the inactive S reactivation of Li-S battery can be realized by the strategies of modulation of the charge/discharge protocol and introduction of the redox mediators. Huang’s research group reactivated the inactive S of Li2S in Li-S battery by a high cutoff voltage of 4.2 V, which improved the capacity from 49 to 1298 mA h g−1 under 300 cycles of operation [110]. Xiao’s group realized the reactive of inactive S by introducing ZnI2 additive to electrolyte. The produced I−/I3 − redox enhanced the utilization of insoluble Li2S and Li2S2 [111]. At present, research on inactive S reactivation is rare, even no report on inactive Se reactivation. The inactive S reactivation strategies can provide guidance for the reactivation of inactive Se in Li-Se battery for their similar reaction process. However, there is still a large research gap in inactive S/Se reactivation. High temperature working conditions (the isolated Se recontacts with the current collector), looking for proper working protocol, or exploring suitable redox mediators may be a direction for efficient inactive S/Se reactivation. 4.2 Li anode protection For Li-Se batteries, except for increasing the utilization of Se, maintaining the reaction activity of Li anode is also critical for achieving high performance. It is widely accepted that the Li plating process involves a series of interfacial Li+ interactions, including Li+ transfer across the SEI, and Li+ diffusion and deposition on the surface of anode. As is shown in Fig. 8 (a), due to the uneven current density on the surface of Li foil, Li+ is priority deposited in electron-rich regions, which leads to the appearance of Li dendrites and further “dead Li” (the inactive Li that cannot participate in the redox reaction) production. In addition, there also exists Li corrosion due to the most negative redox potential (−3.04 V). Moreover, the generated unstable and loose SEI leads to the growth of Li dendrites and also the explored fresh Li accelerates the corrosion rate of the Li anode. Therefore, the Li anode protection can be operated by the following strategies: (1) suppressing the growth of Li dendrites, (2) constructing a stable SEI, (3) reactivating “dead Li”, and (4) reducing Li corrosion. 4.2.1 Suppressing growth of Li dendrites The uneven spatial distribution and excessive local current of Li+ on the surface of the anode result in the generation of Li dendrites. According to Chazalviel's model, the onset time of uneven deposition is inversely proportional to the square of current density (τ≈ J −2) [112]. A porous conductive skeleton with a large surface area was structured to decrease and uniformize the current density on the anode surface as well as reduce the volume expansion. Different from planar current Cu collector, numerous protuberant tips exist on the surface of submicron skeleton of the 3D Cu foil (Fig. 8b), which can uniformize the electric field and function as nucleation sites [113]. This resulted in uniformly dispersed Li growing along the Cu skeleton and eventually forming a relatively even Li. Similar to the porous Cu framework, high surface area of 3D porous carbon can disperse current density on the surface of anode. The light-weight, flexible, and free-standing 3D hollow carbon fiber (3D-HCF) current collector significantly reduced local current density and improved Li deposition behavior [114]. Li was confined within the interspace of the interconnected fibers and hollow tubular fibers without uncontrollable Li dendrites. Moreover, 3D CeO2 [115], Al2O3 [116], and TiO2-based [117] inorganic lithiophilic frameworks can realize the uniform distribution of Li+, also can effectively redistribute Li+ and regulate their deposition behavior from the bottom to the top rather than directly deposited on the surface of the host current collectors or Li metal anode, forming a dense and uniform Li electrodeposits. When the electroplating Li exceeds 5 mA h cm−2, Li dendrites will grow rapidly and gradually cover the surface of Cu framework electrode due to the high nucleation barrier of Li. In addition, carbon host as Li anode collector has poor Li wettability due to the mismatch of polarity between the carbon host and Li metal. Therefore, introducing lithiophilic sites on the surface of anode hosts is necessary to decrease the growth of Li dendrites. The lithiophilic particles can be heteroatoms doping materials, some inorganics (e.g., oxides, sulfides, etc.), polymers, or metal nanoparticles. For example, the nitrogen-enriched carbon sponge with high N-doping level of 9.87 at% enabled spatially homogeneous Li nucleation and achieved a uniform dendrite-free anode [118]. Other muti-heteroatom doped porous carbon materials with a high specific surface area were synthesized with polyacrylonitrile (PAN) [119] or MOF precursors [120]. Lithiophilic nanoseeds, such as ZnO [121], Al2O3 [122], CuO [123], MgO [124], and SnS2 [125], are employed to optimize Li metal anode mainly via forming conductive alloys. For instance, ZnO coated on the MCNCF (multi-level Cu nanofibers on Cu foam) exhibits a much larger Li absorption energy of −3.26 eV than the Cu (111) surface of −0.46 eV (Fig. 8c), revealing that the electrodeposited ZnO layer is much more lithiophilic than the pure Cu framework substrate [126]. Li can selectively nucleate with ZnO on the electrode surface through two consecutive reactions: Li++ZnO → Li2O + Zn, Li++Zn → LiZn. In this case, Li tends to form grains rather than branches. Metal nanoparticles, such as Ag [127], Au [128], Sn [129], Co [130], Zn [131], and Cu [132], can work as heterogeneous seeds for Li deposition owing to their zero or low overpotential of Li nucleation. As shown in Fig. 8(d), two lithiation plateaus of Li x Au formation happened above 0 V, following Li metal nucleation overpotential is essentially zero [133]. Polymers, such as polydopamine, can be used as lithophilic coating on the surface of Li substrate to suppress the formation of Li dendrites. The Li+ first reacts with functional groups (hydroxyl groups or amino-nitrogen functional groups) to form uniformly distributed Li complexing functional groups during Li deposition [134]. These groups worked as nucleation sites are favorable for the uniform and stable deposition of Li metal on the current collector (Fig. 8e), thereby effectively suppressing the formation and growth of Li dendrites. 4.2.2 Constructing a stable SEI Li metal can spontaneously react with almost any available liquid electrolyte to form an SEI on its surface due to the highly negative electrochemical potential of Li+/Li. Due to the shuttle effect of LiPSe, the SEI formed on the Li metal anode surface of Li-Se battery includes Li2Se and Li2Se2, resulting in the loose and low electronic conductivity interface. Constructing a dense and stable SEI to separate LiPSe and Li anode is essential for good electrochemical performance of Li-Se batteries. The SEI can be regulated by electrolyte formulation, including additives, solvents, and Li salts and their concentration. In addition, adding an artificial SEI between Li anode and separator is also a feasible strategy. The high stability and mechanical strength lithium fluoride (LiF) is regarded as one of the most important components of SEI to suppress the growth of Li dendrites. By introducing CuF2 additive to electrolyte, LiF-rich SEI was formed with the reaction of CuF2 + 2Li → 2LiF + Cu. In addition, the F-rich Li salt of lithium oxalyldifluoroborate (LiODFB) can promote the formation of LiF-rich SEI. Besides LiF-rich SEI, nanoscale Al2O3 layer can effectively stabilize the Li/electrolyte interface and protect Li metal anode from corrosion in electrolytes. For instance, Ye et al. added controllable AlCl3 as an additive to react with traces of water in the electrolyte to form a stable Al2O3-rich SEI (Fig. 9 a) [135]. Additives containing alloyable cation (e.g., MgI2, AlI3) can be converted to dense Li-M (M = In, Sn, and Al) alloy protection layer or porous metal network layer with sufficient Li+ diffusion coefficient on Li anode. Adjusting solvent molecular of electrolyte can regulate the composition of SEI. The solvents usually possess lower LUMO, which can priority react with Li to form LiF-rich SEI. Methyl acetate (MA) [136] or fluorinated ether-based co-solvent of 1,1,2,2-tetrafluoro-1-(2,2,2-trifluoroethoxy)ethane (FEE) and 1,1,2,2-tetrafluoro-3-(1,1,2,2-tetrafluoroethoxy)propane (TTE), and 1,2-bis(1,1,2,2-tetrafluoroethoxy)ethane (OFDEE) [137] in carbonate-based LiPF6-FEC-DMC electrolyte were proven to favor the formation of a stable LiF-rich SEI. In addition, the fluorinated ether-based co-solvents of 2,2,3,3-tetrafluoro-1,4-dimethoxylbutane (FDMB) [138] or 1,1,2,2-tetrafluoroethyl 2,2,2-trifluoroethyl ether (TFTFE) [139] in lithium bis(fluorosulfonyl)imide-1,2-diethoxyethane (LiFSI-DEE), ether-solvents of 4-dioxane in LiFSI-DME [140] are also shown their stable SEI forming ability. Through these co-solvent methods, the obtained Li+ solvation structure is good for the production of dense and uniform SEI, which is beneficial to get a Li dendrites-free anode. High-concentration electrolytes (HCEs) can decrease the number of free solvent molecules (Fig. 9b) [141], which reduce the solubility of LiPSe, inhibit the decomposition of electrolyte, and enlarge the electrochemical window of the battery. Different from conditional dilute electrolyte, the anion of Li salt is involved in the Li+ solvation structure and participates in the formation of SEI. Hence, the SEI of HCEs is enriched with high mechanical strength LiF via the decomposition of Li salt. At present, the most suitable Li salts in HCEs are imide salts, such as lithium bis(fluorosulfonyl)imide (LiFSI), LiTFSI, and lithium bis(pentafluoroethanesulfonyl)imide (LiBETI), due to their high solubility and dissociation constant [142]. To decrease the price and viscosity of HCEs, meanwhile keeping high concentration Li+ solvent structure, a kind of localized high-concentration electrolytes (LHCEs) was proposed by introducing a diluent (almost does not dissolve Li salt) to the HCEs electrolyte. The commonly used diluents include bis(2,2,2-trifluoroethyl) ether (BTFE), 1,1,2,2-tetrafluoroethyl-2,2,3,3-tetrafluoropropyl ether (TTE), tris(2,2,2-trifluoroethyl) orthoformate (TFEO), and fluorobenzene (FB). Introducing an artificial SEI to suppress the shuttle of LiPSe and avoid continuous electrolyte consumption is a promising method to obtain a high lifespan battery. The introduced SEI layer should have the properties of high mechanical strength, uniform surface, electronic insulation, and high Li+ diffusion ability. Constructing LiF-rich artificial SEI is an efficient strategy to protect Li anode. The high mechanical strength LiF-rich artificial SEI can be realized by the reaction of fluorinated compounds (CuF2, AlF3, SbF3, etc.) with Li. In addition, polycrystalline Li3N with an exceptionally high Li+ conductivity (approximately 10−3 S cm−1), low electronic conductivity (<10−12 S cm−1) combined with the unique stability of nitride anions to Li metal, becomes a good SEI candidate. The Al2O3 or SiO2 SEI is also available for Li anode protection. In addition, the flexible polymers of PVDF, PAN, PEO-UPy, SF, etc., were proved to be good SEI due to the reaction of their groups with Li+. Combining the advantages of inorganic and polymer, Li et al. fabricated an effective artificial SEI of inorganic/polymer yttria-stabilized zirconia-polyacrylonitrile (YSZ-g-PAN) hybrid hairy nanoparticles. The YSZ NPs accelerate and uniformly distribute the Li+ flux, while the grafted PAN polymer chains maintain good structural integrity. Their combined action enables SEI layer to achieve uniform Li deposition. 4.2.3 Reactivating “dead Li” The growth of Li dendrites and its derived “dead Li” (inactive Li, including the Li0 that is isolated from the current collector and Li+ within the SEI) are difficult to completely avoid, especially at high current densities. Different from the traditional view that “dead Li” is useless, Cui’s group indicated that the “dead Li” can be reversely connected to the cathode (or anode) of Li battery during charging/discharging process through their polarization to realize its activation. In this case, the lifespan of the battery can be extended by 30% [143]. Instead of skipping the Li dendrites formation by dense and uniform SEI and lithophilic sites in most research work, most recently, researchers proposed restoration method by reactivating “dead Li” with redox mediators. Jin et al. introduced triiodide/iodide (I−/I3 −) redox mediators in electrolyte to reactive “dead Li” by their spontaneous response of I3 − with Li2O and Li (Fig. 9c) [144]. The introduced redox mediators may cause severe self-discharge during battery charging. To avoid the self-discharge of redox mediators, redox potentials of the redox mediators should be in the range between the redox potential of the cathode material and the cut-off voltage of the full cell. Chen et al. proved that 10-methylphenothiazine (MPT) and 2,2,6,6-tetrameth-ylpiperidinooxy (TEMPO) can successfully reactivate the “dead Li” with slight self-discharge behaviors beneficial from the redox additive redox potentials are between the redox potential of the cathode material and the cut-off voltage of the full cell (3.8–4.0 V) [145]. Until now, the research work on “dead Li” reactivation is limited, and more research work, such as the identification and quantification of “dead” Li and their influence factors, remains to be uncovered. 4.2.4 Reducing Li corrosion The failure of Li metal anode is actually a metal corrosion process. The corrosion behavior is prevalent in batteries, especially with the most reactive Li. The highly active Li easily automatically reacts with electrolyte to produce SEI on the surface of Li, which is a kind of corrosion. Once the structure of the produced SEI is loose, the electrolyte will contact the freshly exposed Li surface, and the formed activation (fresh Li surface)-passivation layer (SEI) microgalvanic couple accelerates the Li corrosion, leading to pitting corrosion. In addition, with the deep of the charging process, the Cu current collector will be gradually explored, and the remaining Li and explored Cu also generate to microgalvanic couple, which contributes greatly to the corrosion of the Li. Constructing a dense SEI to block the contact Li with electrolyte is an efficient method to cut off the galvanic corrosion, which can be achieved by modification electrolyte or artificial SEI. Kwon et al. modulated a borate-pyran lean electrolyte to passivate the Li/electrolyte interface, which transforms the LiF of SEI from large crystallites into fine crystalline or glassy, minimizing the permeation of electrolyte into the SEI [146]. Jin et al. fabricated an organic-inorganic MgF2@PVDF protection layer to prevent direct contact with Li, and the effectiveness of the anticorrosion layer was successfully demonstrated in button and pouch cells. The 3D host or prelithiated host also decreases the corrosion of Li by the uniform Li+ distribution inhibiting the corrosion caused by the local high concentration distribution [147]. In addition, Huang’s group revealed that the long total step length of Li stripping slow dynamic corrosion current (i corrosion) degradation speed, and porous organic-rich SEI deteriorates the Li corrosion behavior (Fig. 9d) [148]. Meng’s group explored that Li corrosion is also influenced by coin cell pressure and calendar aging. The large surface area of porous property of Li crystal at low coin cell pressure and long calendar aging will accelerate the rate of Li corrosion [149]. For the Li corrosion of the battery, there still are issues remaining. (1) The large surface area of host is good for the uniform Li deposition but may accelerate the Li corrosion, how to balance the parameter? (2) Which kind of artificial SEI is good for suppressing Li corrosion? How much is the property thickness of the SEI layer? (3) Is there some anticorrosive that is suitable for the battery system? (4) Also how to test the corrosion current density and can we look for a stable reference electrode for the electrochemical of the battery? Therefore, there is still a long way to go for Li protection. In summary, by the modification of Li metal anode with the methods of suppressing Li dendrites, constructing stable SEI, reactivity the “dead Li” and reducing Li corrosion, the Li-Se batteries achieve improved performance. Due to the existence of LiPSe in Li-Se battery, the side reaction of dissolved LiPSe with the Li anode is an inevitable issue. Confining LiPS within the solvent shell by adding weakly solvated solvent of DIPS can avoid their direct contact with Li, thereby suppressing the side reactions between LiPS and Li anode. This method provides a new perspective on the Li anode protection and shuttle effect of LiPSe. The confining LiPS method may also be suitable for Li-Se batteries. 4.3 All-solid-state electrolytes Compared with flammable liquid electrolytes, all-solid-state Li batteries (ASSBs) with solid electrolytes not only solve the safety problem of electrolyte leakage but also effectively block the shuttle effect of LiPSe and inhibit the growth of Li dendrites [150]. Moreover, the potential compatibility of solid-sate electrolytes with Li metal anodes permits the battery to achieve high specific energy densities. The all-solid-sate electrolytes mainly include inorganic solid electrolytes (oxides, sulfides, and halides) and solid polymer electrolytes (PEO, PAN, PMMA, and PVDF). The ionic conductivity of inorganic solid electrolytes originates from the movement of point defects, such as vacancies or interstitial ions in the crystal. The inorganic solid electrolytes of oxides, sulfides, and halides have been considered promising candidates in ASSBs. NASICON-type oxide solid electrolyte, such as LiTi2(PO4)3, Li1+ x M x Ti2− x (PO4)3 (M = Al, Cr, Ga, Fe, Sc, In, Lu, Y, or La), Li1+ x Al x Ge2− x (PO4)3, and garnet-type oxide solid electrolyte, such as Li5La3M2O12 (M = Nb or Ta), Li6ALa2M2O12 (A = Ca, Sr or Ba; M = Nb or Ta), Li5.5La3M1.75B0.25O12 (M = Nb or Ta, B = In or Zr) are commonly used. The oxide solid electrolytes have good electrochemical and chemical stabilities even at high temperature, but their large interfacial resistance restricts their application in batteries. Jin et al. synthesized a kind of solid garnet-type Li6.4La3Zr1.4Ta0.6O12 (LLZTO) tube electrolyte and operated at high temperature of 240–300 °C [151]. In this case, Li and Se in liquid phase facilitated rapid ion transport and low electrode-electrolyte interfacial impedance, as liquid-solid interfaces were formed instead of solid-solid interfaces. Meanwhile, the shuttle effects of LiPSe were prevented by the compact ceramic LLZTO tube. Sulfides become members of the solid electrolyte due to their high ionic conductivity and good deformability. The sulfide solid electrolytes mainly include Li-P-S-based glasses and glass ceramics, Li6PS5X (X = Cl, Br, or I) argyrodites, thio-LISICONs, and Li11− x M2− x P1+ x S12 (M = Ge, Sn, and Si) compounds [152]. For instance, Li et al. fabricated a novel all-solid-state Li-Se battery by pressing the commercial Li3PS4 powder [153]. The Li+ transport over the Se-Li3PS4 interface is as high as 1.4 × 10−5 S cm−1, and the LiPSe diffusion was greatly reduced. However, Li3PS4 is electrochemically unstable when in direct contact with Li metal anode, which leads to the formation of a large interfacial resistance and overshadows the advantages of sulfide solid electrolyte. There needs further efforts to solve the low stability problem of sulfides. Halide solid electrolytes are recently considered research hotspots in the field of ASSBs for the advantages of high ionic conductivity, credible deformability, and good stability. For example, Li et al. synthesized Li3HoCl6 solid electrolyte in Li-Se battery. The battery achieved a reversible capacity of 402 mA h g−1 after 750 cycles [154]. Shi et al. fabricated Li3HoBr6 (LHB) electrolyte by the vacuum evaporation-assisted method [155]. The ionic conductivity of the prepared large-scale LHB achieved a high value of 1.25 ± 0.08 × 10−3 S cm−1. The LHB-based Li-Se ASSBs exhibited a specific capacity of 500 mA h g−1 after 150 cycles with high CE close to 100% and excellent rate performances. Solid polymer electrolyte is also a promising solid-state-electrolyte due to its high flexibility, ease of processing, and good interfacial contact with electrode. Solid polymer electrolytes achieve ionic conductivity by segmental motion of polymer chains. Coordinated with the polar groups of polymers, Li+ hop from one coordinating site to another nearby one. The polyethylene oxide (PEO) based polymer electrolytes have been widely used in ASSBs. In addition, polyacrylonitrile (PAN), polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF), polymethyl methacrylate (PMMA), etc., are also commonly used as solid polymer electrolytes. However, these kinds of pure solid polymer electrolytes have low ionic conductivity at ambient temperatures. Therefore, the solid polymer electrolyte battery should operate at high temperature. Adding some high conductivity ceramic particles into solid polymer electrolyte becomes an efficient method to solve this problem by decreasing the glass transition temperatures. All-solid-state electrolytes can suppress the shuttle effects of LiPSe and growth of Li dendrites, but raise new problems of sluggish kinetics and poor interfacial contact. In addition, different types of solid electrolytes have their shortages in chemical stability, ionic conductivity, or high interface impedance, which restricts the development of all-solid-state Li battery. The in-situ grown all-solid electrolyte and hybrid electrolytes may be effective solutions to solve the problem of all-solid-state electrolyte Li-Se batteries. The main problems restricting the development of all-solid-state batteries are the ion transport mechanism of solid electrolytes, the growth mechanism of Li dendrites on Li anode, and the failure mechanism of multi-field coupling systems.
