The growth of Li dendrites is an important factor hindering the practical application of all-solid-state batteries (Li dendrite growth may result in short circuits even in high shear modulus oxide solid electrolytes). Degeneration of the solid-solid interface contact is another major cause of battery failure. In addition, the cost of solid-state battery electrode materials is still high. All the above issues need to be paid attention in the future all-solid-state electrolyte design. 4.4 “one pot” strategies for shuttle effects reduction and Li anode protection The shuttle effect of LiPSe is one of the most decisive factors for the fast capacity decay of Li-Se batteries. To solve the shuttle effects problem, a series of solutions have been proposed in the aspect of high ratio Se maintenance, such as constructing porous frameworks to alleviate volume expansion, locking LiPSe transportation, and accelerating the reaction kinetics of LiPSe conversion by catalysts. In addition to the problem of shuttle effects, protecting Li anode from deactivation and continuous electrolyte consumption is also important to extend the lifespan of Li-Se batteries. The Li protection can be achieved by suppressing Li dendrites, constructing a stable SEI, reactivity “dead” Li and suppressing Li corrosion. Compared with the modification methods of cathode and anode of Li-Se battery, it is surprising to find that there exist many similar strategies in the battery modification. For instance, by constructing all-solid-state electrolytes, Li-Se battery can reduce the transfer of LiPSe and at the same time, suppress the growth of Li dendrites. Therefore, utilizing these similarities to solve the problems of shuttle effect and Li protection by “one pot” strategy will be a good strategy to achieve high performance Li-Se batteries. In detail, the 3D porous carbon frameworks can be used as host material of active Se in cathode and current corrector of Li+ deposition. In addition, proper polar sites on frameworks provide strong adsorption to LiPSe and also can be worked as lithiophilic sites to decrease the Li growth energy barrier. Regulation of electrolyte formations to form a dense solid interphase or inserting an artificial CEI/SEI layer will efficiently suppress the shuttle effects and Li protection. The “one-pot” solution to the shuttling effect and Li protection of Li-Se batteries has great significance in improving the overall performance of Li-Se batteries. 4.5 Advanced characterization technologies The effective modification is related to the deep understanding of the reaction mechanism of the Li-Se battery, which relies on advanced characterization methods. The advanced characterization methods are classified into three fields. (1) Visualizing morphology in higher dimensions and resolutions. Cryo-TEM working at −170 °C could freeze the reaction state and avoid the destruction of the structure by high energy X-ray, which is critical for detecting the morphology and structure of the electronic radiation-sensitive active materials. For example, the chemical composition of produced SEI was proven to be dependent on current collector materials, electrolytes, and additives as well as formation conditions (temperature, current density, etc.) in the Cryo-TEM results of Fig. 10 (a) [156]. In addition, the SEI organic components dissolution phenomenon during calendar aging [157], and the atomic resolution structure of metal dendrites (analysis of the crystal face behavior of metal dendrites) (Fig. 10b) [158] can be explored by Cryo-TEM. Moreover, the Cryo-TEM may achieve precise analysis of polyselenides at atomic scale by instantaneously cooling them to stability under an electron beam. (2) Real-time monitoring of the realistic battery. The in-situ optical microscopy could effectively track the dynamic structural and chemical evolution process of the battery system [159]. Steiger et al. visualize Li nucleation and growth induced from the substrate lithium interface, at kinks, in a region at or close to the tip using in-situ optical microscopy [160]. Cui’s group observed the isolated Li formation and reconnection behavior under continuous cycling, which provides direct evidence for the “dead Li” reactivation [157]. Wen’s group monitored the S cathode surface cracking morphological evolution, which was accompanied by irreversible volume deformation, color transition, and bubble generation of the solid electrolyte [161]. In-situ TEM is also an efficient high-resolution technology for real-time monitoring analysis, such as the Li dendrites growth and stripping process, and the influence of Li morphology on the Li stripping and deposition behaviors. Zhou et al. observed that the metal nanoclusters active centers gathered soluble LiPSs into droplet-like dense phase and Li2S crystals are instantaneously induced instead of the classical step-by-step transformation (Fig. 10c) [162]. Wang et al. analyzed the Li2S conversion behavior dependent on the depth of electrochemical lithiation and temperature [163]. (3) Components and quantitative analysis. The components and the quantity of the active species are important parameters for the kinetics reaction, which can be analyzed by the in-situ XRD, in-situ Raman, or in-situ NMR technologies. In-situ XRD was applied to determine the phase composition and crystallinity of materials in the battery operation process. Cañas et al. investigated the structural change of the reaction from S to high-ordered LiPS, and then Li2S by in-situ XRD [164]. The in-situ Raman can effectively probe the presence of various LiPS forms and measure LiPS evolution during battery operation. The limited reaction steps of the reaction, accelerated kinetics of catalysts, and the function of the electrolyte additives can be explored [165]. Liu et al. conducted statistical analysis and mechanism research on elemental sulfur and polysulfides in different states of Li-S batteries by in-situ Ramna, providing theoretical support for exploring the sulfur loss path (Fig. 10d) [166]. The different existing forms of Li and S can be probed by NMR by their electronic/chemical environment around the Li and S nucleus. The formation and quantification of the “dead Li” of Li metal battery were tracked and detected by in-situ NMR by Clare P. Grey’s group. The peak of Li after Li stripping is attributed to the “dead Li”, and the “dead Li” accumulation increases with the following cycles [167]. In-situ NMR spectroscopy provided the complex electrochemistry of LiPS formation in Li-S battery, such as the final products after fully discharging, and the accumulation of the irreversible Li2S product during cycling. We have to note that the obtained quantification result of these above technologies is just the relative content, which is related to the detected peak density, and also the in-situ Raman and NMR technologies give the information of the small local area instead of the whole battery. Meng’s group developed the titration gas chromatography (TGC) to distinguish the absolute content of Li0 and Li+ of SEI, and given the absolute value of “dead Li” [168]. Most advanced technologies are popularly used in Li-S battery; however, the research on Li-Se is rare. Attributed to their similar reaction process, these technologies will give important guidance for Li-Se batteries to deeply understand the reaction mechanism. However, these advanced technologies have problems with high equipment requirements, harsh implementation environments, and supporting localized information. Looking for more simple and low-price methods is critically needed. In addition to the above material characterization technology, chemical analysis is also an important parameter to analyze the undergoing reaction. The three-electrode electrochemical techniques can realize separate analyses of the electrochemical behavior of the cathode and anode in a cell to avoid the influence of each other. In the three-electrode electrochemical system, the Li metal is used as a reference electrode, but with the problem of instability (joins the plating and striping reaction, performance SEI on its surface). Looking for a stable reference electrode still has a great challenge. 4.6 Parameters for evaluating Li-Se battery The performance of Li-Se batteries is a result of comprehensive factors. Using parameters to evaluate the performance is essential to achieve optimized batteries, especially for the “one pot” strategy on batteries. The modification strategies are conducted in cathode, anode, electrolyte, and separator focusing on the problems of volume expansion of electrode, shuttle effects of LiPSe, growth of Li dendrites, and low ionic conductivity. In order to intuitively evaluate the contribution of different modification strategies and components, looking for normalized parameter indicators is crucial. Moreover, exploring the comprehensive evaluation parameters of cycle stability, rate capability, safety, flammability, and price of the batteries is necessary to evaluate and select viable battery systems. Defining widely accepted standards is urgently needed to evaluate the practicability of the battery. With the help of advanced artificial intelligence (AI) simulation to properly evaluate comprehensive performance, the selection process of promising batteries can be significantly accelerated. 5 Summary In recent decades, research on the high energy density Li-Se batteries has made great progress. This paper mainly discusses the issues of rapid capacity decay caused by the loss of active Se, including the volume expansion induced cracks and peeling off of cathode, shuttle effect of LiPSe. The construction of cathode materials and the introduced catalytic sites have made contributions to improving the performance of Li-Se battery. The inactive Se reactivation gives a new perspective for high Se utilization. The performance of battery does not just depend on the Se cathode but also on all the parts of its composition. Some prospects are proposed in terms of Li metal anode protection and designing all-solid-state electrolytes. Additionally, according to the same modification strategies of cathode and anode of Li-Se batteries, the “one pot” method for shuttle effect alleviation and Li metal anode stabilization will be a promising direction for future efforts. The advanced characterization technologies support the in-depth study of the reaction mechanism of Li-Se battery. In addition, establishing a practical and objective evaluation standard of the battery is essential and has important practical significance for the development of Li-Se battery. Moreover, continuous technological innovations and breakthroughs in the development of Li-Se battery by exploring new materials and new theories may be a new direction to achieving bright prospects. Gu, K. Xu, X. Wang, Y. S. Meng, Nature 572 (2019) 511–515. Hongyan Li received her PhD degree in 2022 from the University of Namur, Inorganic Materials Chemistry (CMI). She currently works at the College of Materials and Chemistry, China Jiliang University. Her research interests mainly focus on Lithium-selenium battery, Lithium-ion battery, and Lithium anode protection. Cheng-Bin Jin received his Ph.D. from the Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Zhejiang University of Technology, in 2020. He is currently a professor at the College of Materials and Chemistry, China Jiliang University. His research interest focuses on the interfacial chemistry and material of lithium metal batteries. Yu Li received his B.S. from Xi’an Jiaotong University in 1999 and received his M.S. from Liaoning Shihua University in 2002. He obtained his Ph.D. from Zhejiang University in 2005. He worked in EMAT at the University of Antwerp with Prof. G. Vantendeloo in 2005 and then in CMI at the University of Namur with Prof. Bao-Lian Su in 2006. Currently, he is a full-time Professor at Wuhan University of Technology. His research interests include nanomaterials design and synthesis, hierarchically porous materials synthesis, and their applications in the fundamental aspects of energy and environment. Bao-Lian Su created the Laboratory of Inorganic Materials Chemistry (CMI) at the University of Namur, Belgium in 1995. He is currently Full Professor of Chemistry, Member of the Royal Academy of Belgium, Fellow of the Royal of Society of Chemistry, UK and Life Member of Clare Hall College, University of Cambridge. He is also Changjiang Professor and a strategy scientist at Wuhan University of Technology, China. His current research fields include the synthesis, the property study and the molecular engineering of organized, hierarchically porous and bio-organisms for artificial photosynthesis, (photo) Catalysis, Energy Conversion and Storage, Biotechnology, Cell therapy and Biomedical applications.

coredata.dc:description: Lithium-selenium (Li-Se) batteries have attracted increasing attention as one of the next-generation battery systems due to much higher electronic conductivity and comparable volumetric capacity of Se compared to the popular sulfur cathode. However, its practical application still faces great challenges, especially the rapid capacity decay triggered by the loss of active Se species. A comprehensive review to uncover the in-depth failure mechanism and provide targeted solutions to promote the stable operation of Li-Se batteries is urgently needed. This review systematically summarizes the strategies in the new perspective, focusing on the optimization of Se utilization in Li-Se batteries by keeping a high Se maintenance in the cathode and accelerating the electrochemical kinetics of lithium polyselenides (LiPSe) conversion. On the basis of structural design and Li2Se active material introduction to accommodate volume expansion, blocking shuttle transport of LiPSe by physical/chemical adsorption, bonding Se with polymers or cathode electrolyte interphase (CEI) construction, and catalytic design to accelerate the conversion of LiPSe, different strategies for improving the utilization of Se have been evaluated and discussed. To address the inevitable loss of Se, prospects on inactive Se reactivation and Li protection are detailedly proposed and analyzed referring to the chemistry and corrosion science. Additionally, the perspectives on the future design and comprehensive parameter evaluations for the optimization of Li-Se batteries are recommended. This review comprehensively explains the causes and solutions of capacity fading and provides potential efforts for lifespan expansion of batteries, shedding light on the future development of Li-Se batteries.
